title: Hub gears in the WorldTour: Campenaerts to race on Classified Powershift hub
content:
Cyclist
Hub gears in the WorldTour: Campenaerts to race on Classified Powershift hub

Pro rider Victor Campenaerts has confirmed that he’ll be using a Powershift hub-equipped bike for the upcoming season, following the announcement of a partnership between Classified, DT Swiss and Ridley.

The Belgian pro has been testing the setup for over a year in training and is now ready to use it in races. He used the Classified hub in the GP Le Samyn on Tuesday 28th February where he made it into the break and helped set up his teammate Milan Menten for the win.

Campenaerts is renowned for his preference for exceptionally large chainrings – he’s using an immense 62-tooth chainring on his new Powershift setup – and said the decision to use the internally geared hub was simple. ‘I am riding Classified because it is by the far the most efficient setup for the bike’, said Campenaerts. ‘It allows me to ditch the front derailleur, shift gears under full load and run a bigger chainring.’

Given that he set the Hour record (since toppled) in Mexico in 2019, the Belgian knows a thing or two about speed and efficiency. While individual endorsements help bring credibility to a brand, the tech underpinning the Powershift hub speaks for itself to an extent, and it was awarded the Design & Innovation Award for road components in 2021.

How could the Powershift hub benefit pro riders?

Founded in 2019, Classified set out to remove the need for front derailleurs on bicycles with its Powershift hub. We know the design can benefit everyday riders – see our full Powershift hub review – but many have remained sceptical about its potential in the professional ranks.

Classified says the advantages can be broken down into several key points, which we’ll look at in-depth below.

  • Increased aerodynamic performance
  • Reduced chain force
  • Shifting under full load
  • Capacity for more frequent shifting
  • Reduced risk of chain drop
  • Equal access to optimal cadence
  • Increased aerodynamic performance

Powershift hubs use a planetary gear system, housing two different ratios within the rear wheel hub, either 1:1 – direct drive, like riding a standard hub – or 0.7 – activating reduction gear, equivalent to riding in the small chainring on a 2× setup.

The system is designed to remove the need for a front derailleur and a two-chainring crankset. Without these elements, Classified claims this can reduce the aerodynamic drag on the bike by up to 1%.

Reduced chain force

With no front derailleur, and technically operating like a 1× drivetrain, the Classified system allows riders to use bigger chainrings and sprockets, as chainring size is not restricted by the front derailleur and the chain can be longer without causing you to run out of derailleur capacity.

Classified says that using larger sprockets and chainrings reduces chain bend, which reduces the chain force by up to 45%. The higher the chain force, the higher the overall friction, which can negatively affect the efficiency of the drivetrain by up to 1% according to the brand.

Shifting under full load

Professional road courses are intended to test riders to their max, whether that be in length, terrain or the amount of climbing included. On climbs, having the ability to change gear under hard pedalling without increasing the risk of a mechanical failure is an obvious advantage.

The Powershift hub can shift seamlessly under loads up to 1,000W according to Classified, which would certainly give those using it an added advantage not only on climbs, but also for surprise accelerations or to follow an unexpected attack.

Capacity for more frequent shifting

Classified claims the Powershift hub allows riders to shift more frequently, though the brand doesn’t mention what this is in comparison to. The assumption is that this is linked to another other claim – that the shifting on its hub is ‘instant’, taking just 150 milliseconds.

If this is accurate, it would be logical to extrapolate that, with the instantaneous shifting, riders can switch between the two planetary gear ratios at will, rather than having to wait for the chain to move between chainrings as they would with a standard externally geared system.

Reduced risk of chain drop

We’ve all seen the devastated look of a rider trying to get their chain back on after it has fallen off, watching the rest of the peloton rush by as they struggle to fix their bike in a hurry.

When a front derailleur is used under load, it can jam or cause the chain to fall off the chainrings. By doing away with the front derailleur, Classified says it has drastically reduced the risk of dropped chains.

While technically not a performance gain in the traditional sense, stopping to fix a dropped chain is obviously an inefficient use of time, and reducing the risk of this happening is a useful side effect of the Powershift hub’s other advantages.

Equal access to optimal cadence

1× drivetrains can offer some of the aforementioned benefits, such as improved aerodynamics or reduced risk of chain drop but come at the cost of limited gear selection. 1× drivetrains typically feature bigger incremental jumps from gear to gear to allow the cassette to cover sufficient range.

As the Powershift hub system provides two gear ratios within the hub itself, the need for a wide range cassette is largely mitigated. Riders still have access to the smaller steps between gears and the same combination of gear options as a conventional 2× drivetrain, which allows them to ride at their optimal cadence in a given scenario.

Many are still put off by the idea of an internal hub, conflating the idea with those seen on hybrid and city bikes. These systems typically use an internal hub to replace both the front and rear derailleur and, as such, tend to house between three and 11 gears.

Given the intended use and the greater number of internal gears, these hubs are generally quite heavy and wouldn’t be suitable for a pro-level race bike.

The Powershift hub, on the other hand, is comparably light at a claimed 475g. Factor in that it removes the need for a front derailleur and a small chainring, and uses a lightweight cassette – just 190g claimed weight – and weight becomes less of an issue.

Classified hopes to dispel general apprehensions about the concept with the likes of Campenaerts using its tech. We’ll be watching with interest this season to see whether the system can perform at the highest levels of the sport.
